hypotheses: Counties with lower socioeconomic status will have lower engagement in social distancing.
Counties with a greater Republican orientation will have lower engagement in social distancing.
claim.statement: The U.S. is the epicenter of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic. In response, governments have implemented measures to slow transmission through 'social distancing.' However, the practice of social distancing may depend on prevailing socioeconomic conditions and beliefs.

data.source: Unacast, American Community Survey (ACS), MIT Election Data and Science Lab
data.notes: Anonymized cell phone records; potential measurement error as not all cell-phone users are included.

method.description: The study examines the associations of county-level socioeconomic and political characteristics with social distancing using cross-sectional ordinary least squares regressions.
steps: Collect cell phone data representing county-level averages of distance traveled.
Measure social distancing by changes in average distance traveled from March 19–28, 2020.
Gather socioeconomic data from ACS and political preference data from MIT Election Data and Science Lab.
Adjust for sociodemographic and labor market characteristics as well as state fixed effects.
Perform cross-sectional OLS regressions to estimate associations.
method.independent_variables: Income per capita, 2016 county-level vote share for President Trump
method.control_variables: Sociodemographic covariates, state fixed effects, rurality

results.summary: Lower per capita income and greater Republican orientation were associated with reduced social distancing. An increase in per capita income resulted in higher social distancing, while increased support for Trump resulted in decreased social distancing.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Social distancing increase per I.Q.R. increase in per capita income
Social distancing decrease per I.Q.R. increase in support for Trump

metadata.original_paper_title: Association of County-Level Socioeconomic and Political Characteristics with Engagement in Social Distancing for COVID-19
